Between 11 and 24 June, the security situation in eastern Ukraine remained volatile. The Mission recorded fewer ceasefire violations along the contact line – around 13,000, representing a 10 per cent decrease compared with the previous two-week reporting period. Also, the use of weapons that should have been withdrawn in accordance with the Minsk agreements decreased by 30 per cent.

The SMM corroborated 16 civilian casualties due to armed violence, all of whom were injured. This brings the total number of civilian casualties confirmed by the Mission this year to 144, including 29 fatalities. Other cases are pending verification.

The Mission’s unarmed civilian monitors continued to face a host of restrictions, risks and threats. In one incident on 14 June, in non-government-controlled Pikuzy, warning shots were fired 50m from SMM monitors (Spot Report: www.osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-to-ukraine/384540). On 23 June, in nongovernment-controlled Petrivske, a member of the armed formations with an assault rifle (AK-74) forced the SMM to drive on a mine-contaminated road (Spot Report: www.osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-toukraine/385626). In addition, ground patrols were actively restricted 31 times; denied or delayed access, or only granted access conditionally – 29 times by members of the armed formations and twice by Ukrainian Armed Forces’ soldiers.

The Mission’s aerial monitoring was subject to restrictions as well. On 15 June, over non-governmentcontrolled Betmanove, an SMM long-range unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) was fired at by a surface-to-air missile system and an anti-aircraft gun. (Spot Report: https://www.osce.org/special-monitoring-mission-toukraine/384642). On 18 June, small-arms fire was directed at an SMM mini-UAV near Petrivske. On nine occasions, control over SMM UAVs was temporarily lost, most probably due to electronic jamming, on both sides of the contact line.
